title: Bump versions to prereleases
body: Now that #515 which upgrades to prereleases of the `elliptic-curve` and `ecdsa` crates has been merged, bump the version numbers of all crates to prereleases to indicate breaking changes have been made.

title: Fix `hash2curve` crate feature
body: The `hash2curve` crate feature actually requires the `arithmetic` crate feature. The reason why CI didn't catch it is because any tests using `hash2curve` are hidden behind modules behind the `arithmetic` crate feature.

title: p256 v0.10.1
body:
### Added
- Impl `ff::Field` trait for `FieldElement` ([#498])
- hash2curve support: impl `GroupDigest` trait for `NistP256` ([#503])
- Impl `VoprfParameters` trait for `NistP256` ([#506])
- Impl `ReduceNonZero<U256>` trait for `Scalar` ([#507])
- `IDENTITY` and `GENERATOR` point constants ([#509], [#511])

[#498]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/pull/498
[#503]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/pull/503
[#506]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/pull/506
[#507]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/pull/507
[#509]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/pull/509
[#511]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/pull/511

title: k256 v0.10.3
body:
### Added
- hash2curve support: impl `GroupDigest` for `Secp256k1` ([#503])
- `IDENTITY` and `GENERATOR` point constants ([#511])

[#503]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/pull/503
[#511]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/pull/511

title: k256+p256: move `Scalar` impl blocks to top of module
body: Reorders the impl blocks containing inherent constants/methods to the top of the module, following suit with how the `affine` and `projective` modules have been reorganized.

title: Update elliptic-curve, digest and ecdsa
body: This builds on RustCrypto/traits#883 and RustCrypto/signatures#433.

title: p384: rename arithmetic feature to `broken-arithmetic-do-not-use`
body:
The arithmetic implementations as they currently exist are known to be broken, so to prevent someone from accidentally attempting to use them unknowingly, renames the feature to `broken-arithmetic-do-not-use`.

Additionally removes the derived `invert` and `sqrt` methods.

title: p256: consolidate `ProjectivePoint` impl blocks
body: Moves the inherent method definitions to the same impl block as the one that defines the `IDENTITY` and `GENERATOR` constants.

title: k256: `IDENTITY` and `GENERATOR` point constants
body:
Adds inherent constants to `AffinePoint` and `ProjectivePoint` representing the identity and generator points.

This should make it possible to write `const fn`s that produce things like precomputed basepoint tables (see #508).

Deprecates the previous inherent methods on `ProjectivePoint` for returning these constants.

title: p256: `IDENTITY` and `GENERATOR` point constants
body:
Adds inherent constants to `AffinePoint` and `ProjectivePoint` representing the identity and generator points.

This should make it possible to write `const fn`s that produce things like precomputed basepoint tables (see #508).

Deprecates the previous inherent methods on `ProjectivePoint` for returning these constants.

title: p256: make `AffinePoint::generator` closer to const-friendly
body:
This is a stepping stone towards solving #508 for `p256`.

Replaces the implementation of `AffinePoint::generator` with one that uses Rust literal syntax to construct the field elements which represent the base point's affine coordinates.

Coordinates are specified in canonical form for easy auditability, then converted to Montgomery form. With `const fn`, this conversion could happen completely at compile time.

This can't yet be made fully `const` though, as there isn't a `const fn` constructor for `subtle::Choice`, which is used to represent the point at infinity.

title: Implement `ReduceNonZero<U256>` for `p256::Scalar`
body: IANA cryptographer, I basically copied this from k256.

title: Implement `VoprfParameters` for `NistP256` and `NistP384`
body:
See RustCrypto/traits#878.
Reference: https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-irtf-cfrg-voprf-08.html#section-4.

title: Implement `GroupDigest` for `NistP256` and `Secp256k1`
body:
See RustCrypto/traits#865.
This replaces #495 where I copied some code from @mikelodder7. The reason I did that is to test changes, for example, for RustCrypto/traits#871.

Currently builds on top of RustCrypto/traits#876.

title: k256 v0.10.1
body:
### Added
- Impl `ff::Field` trait for `FieldElement` ([#498])
- Impl `ReduceNonZero<U256>` for `Scalar` ([#501])

[#498]: https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/pull/498

title: k256: add impl of `ReduceNonZero<U256>` for `Scalar`
body:
- add impl of `ReduceNonZero<U256>` for `Scalar`
- fix a bug in `WideScalar::reduce_nonzero()` (a zero value returned when reducing `MODULUS-1`)

Very embarrassing for me, but at least chances of someone hitting it were astronomically small, and if they did, it most probably resulted in a panic during inversion or something of the sort.

title: k256+p256: impl `ff::Field` trait for `FieldElement` types
body: Allows for writing code which is generic over field elements, such as the optimized SWU implementation added in RustCrypto/traits#854

title: p384: factor `Scalar::mul` into an inherent method
body: An inherent method is easier to constify, although that isn't possible until `Scalar::montgomery_reduce` is `const fn`, which requires a `const fn` implementation of conditionally subtracting the modulus.

title: p384: add basic tests for `Scalar` arithmetic
body:
Currently not passing and flagged with `#[ignore]`.

Also moves `montgomery_reduce` into the `Scalar` type as a static method

title: p384: add `FieldElement::{to_canonical, to_montgomery}`
body:
Adds wrappers for fiat-crypto's `fiat_p384_from_montgomery` and `fiat_p384_to_montgomery`, using them to translate field elements into and out of the Montgomery domain when decoding or encoding them from big endian-serialized canonical form.

Also ensures field element constants are already in Montgomery form.

title: p384: add `AffinePoint`
body:
Partial implementation of `AffinePoint`, with coordinates internally represented using `FieldElement` type which wraps fiat-crypto's base field arithmetic.

With this in place, `FieldElement` can be removed from the public API without any warnings about dead code.

Note: the implementation is not yet fully correct and some of the tests have been flagged with `#[ignore]`.

title: p384: base field arithmetic
body:
Vendors formally verified secp384r1 base field arithmetic generated by the fiat-crypto project:

https://github.com/mit-plv/fiat-crypto/tree/master/fiat-rust

The generated code is triple licensed Apache 2.0, MIT, and BSD.

Vendored code comes from the following commit:

https://github.com/mit-plv/fiat-crypto/commit/c92bed39e597f875536c4c70a37ae09909acabae

Commit: c92bed39e597f875536c4c70a37ae09909acabae (tag: v0.0.10)
Author: brycx <brycx@protonmail.com>
Date:   Mon Dec 13 09:37:54 2021 +0100
Title:  Update generated Rust files

title: p384: scalar arithmetic
body:
Note: currently 64-bit only

Adds an initial scalar arithmetic backend combining `crypto-bigint` and `elliptic_curve::ScalarCore`-based functionality with arithmetic generated using the `ff_derive` crate for functions that `crypto-bigint` presently doesn't support.

Constants such as the multiplicative generator and root of unity calculated using SageMath:

```sage
sage: n = 0xffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffc7634d81f4372ddf581a0db248b0a77aecec196accc52973
sage: GF(n).primitive_element()
2
sage: s = 1
sage: t = (n - 1) >> s
sage: t
19701003098197239606139520050071806902539869635232723333973452639813829699556631784699478154076147456777216826971321
sage: power_mod(2,t,n)
39402006196394479212279040100143613805079739270465446667946905279627659399113263569398956308152294913554433653942642
```

title: k256+p256: use revised `LinearCombination` trait
body: See RustCrypto/traits#835

title: Cargo.lock: bump dependencies
body: Picks up `ecdsa` v0.13.2 released in https://github.com/RustCrypto/signatures/pull/418

title: k256+p256: impl `LinearCombination` trait
body:
Adds impls of traits for linear combinations added in RustCrypto/traits#833:

- `k256` uses an optimized implementation.
- `p256` uses the default unoptimized implementation.

title: Documentation improvements
body:
- Use `doc = include_str!` attribute to include README.md
- Add documentation for `serde` features

title: k256: impl `ReduceNonZero<U512>` for `Scalar`
body:
Provides an impl of the `ReduceNonZero` trait added in [RustCrypto/elliptic-curves#827](https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/827), which provides a reduction from a 512-bit (64-byte) input, i.e. a "wide" reduction from an integer twice the size of the curve's order, to a `Scalar` which is guaranteed to be non-zero.

Based on @fjarri's work in #432

title: k256: use `ecdsa::hazmat::rfc6979_generate_k`
body:
The extraction of the RFC6979 implementation in the `ecdsa` crate into the `rfc6979` crate resulted in a suboptimal API for general use.

This commit uses a helper function added in `ecdsa` v0.13.1 which simplifies the API.

title: k256: impl `Reduce<U512>` for `Scalar`
body:
Adds a second impl of the `Reduce` trait for `Scalar` (where the first was `U256`).

This provides a simple thunk to `WideScalar::reduce`.

title: .cargo/audit.toml: initial config with RUSTSEC-2021-0127
body:
Ignores `RUSTSEC-2021-0127`: `serde_cbor` is unmaintained

This is a transitive dependency of `criterion`

title: p256 v0.10.0-pre.1
body:
This pre-release includes upgrades to the following:

- `ecdsa` v0.13
- `elliptic-curve` v0.11
  - `ff` v0.11
  - `group` v0.11

title: k256 v0.10.0-pre.1
body:
This pre-release includes upgrades to the following:

- `ecdsa` v0.13
- `elliptic-curve` v0.11
  - `ff` v0.11
  - `group` v0.11

title: Bump `elliptic-curve` crate dependency to v0.11
body: Release notes: https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/821

title: p256: add serde `Serialize`/`Deserialize` impls
body:
Adds impls of `serde` traits for the following types:

- `AffinePoint`
- `Scalar`

title: k256: add serde `Serialize`/`Deserialize` impls
body:
Adds impls of `serde` traits for the following types:

- `AffinePoint`
- `Scalar`
- `ecdsa::VerifyingKey`

title: Add `serde` feature
body: Adds a `serde` feature to all crates which activates the corresponding `serde` feature in the `ecdsa`, `elliptic-curve`, and `sec1` crates.

title: Update `ecdsa` crate and leverage generic ECDSA implementations
body:
This updates the crates in this repo to leverage the following generic implementations recently added to the `ecdsa` crate:

- Sign: RustCrypto/signatures#396
- Verify: RustCrypto/signatures#397

The `p256` crate is able to directly utilize the generic implementation from the `ecdsa` crate.

The `k256` crate retains its previous custom implementation, which provides a secp256k1-specific take on public key recovery, but can also directly leverage optimizations for computing linear combinations, which there are not presently traits in `elliptic-curve` or `group` to express.

title: k256: remove deprecated `SigningKey::verify_key` method
body: It has been renamed to `SigningKey::verifying_key` instead.

title: Use released RustCrypto/formats crates
body: Removes the git-based dependencies

title: Update `pkcs8` crate
body: Updates to the latest git version of the `pkcs8` crate, which uses `TryFrom` to handle the final step of decoding keys

title: Bump dependencies
body: Updates to the latest `elliptic-curve` and RustCrypto/formats crates

title: Remove `TryFrom`/`TryInto` imports
body: Now that we've upgraded to Rust 2021 edition, these are now available via the prelude, making explicit imports redundant.

title: Rust 2021 edition upgrade; MSRV 1.56+
body:
The `elliptic-curve` and `ecdsa` crates as well as format parsers including `der`, `sec1`, and `pkcs8` have all been bumped to Rust 2021 edition:

- https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/795
- https://github.com/RustCrypto/signatures/pull/384

This commit updates the crates in this repo accordingly.

title: Bump `pkcs8` crate; update encoding traits
body: Updates `pkcs8` and related crates to use the new trait names after they were renamed in RustCrypto/formats#121.

title: Use prerelease format parsers
body: Pull in the prerelease format parsers so we can properly integration test them for the elliptic curve use case.

title: k256: impl `Drop` for `ecdsa::SigningKey`
body: Adds a `Drop` handler which calls `zeroize()` on the `NonZeroScalar` which the `SigningKey` newtype wraps.

title: k256+p256: handle identity point in `GroupEncoding`
body:
`GroupEncoding` uses a fixed-width `Repr` whereas SEC1 is variable-width with respect to compressed points versus the identity.

This change allows 33-bytes of zeroes to be used as the identity. Technically that's not a valid SEC1 encoding: the SEC1 encoding for the identity is 1-byte: 0x00. However, this is the best we can do with a fixed-width encoding.

See also: #443 and #444

title: k256+p256: make `FromEncodedPoint` return a `CtOption`
body:
Corresponding changes for:

https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/782

Internally these were already returning `CtOption` anyway. It should also simplify the implementation of `GroupEncoding`.

title: Fix `to_bytes()` for `ProjectivePoint::identity()`
body:
This could maybe alternatively be fixed "upstream" in `EncodedPoint::len()`?
Fixes #442.

title: k256+p256: replace `ecdsa::hazmat::FromDigest` with `Reduce`
body:
The `FromDigest` trait has been removed from the `ecdsa` crate, in favor of using the `Reduce` trait:

https://github.com/RustCrypto/signatures/pull/372

This is the corresponding set of changes to the above upstream PR to the `ecdsa` crate which implements this change.

title: Use the `sec1` v0.1 crate release
body: Bumps `elliptic-curve` and `ecdsa` git hashes and removes patch dependencies for `der` and `sec1`.

title: k256+p256: impl `Reduce` trait on `Scalar` types
body:
Adds trait impls to `k256::Scalar` and `p256::Scalar` for the newly introduced `Reduce` trait, replacing the previous inherent methods:

https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/768

title: Updates for `sec1` crate
body:
These code changes are necessary to support a migration to the `sec1` crate, which extracted types like `EncodedPoint` into a separate reusable crate.

Relevant `elliptic-curve` PR:

https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/771

title: Bump `elliptic-curve` crate; add `sec1` crate patches
body:
Updates `elliptic-curve` to a new version which uses the (unreleased) `sec1 crate.

See RustCrypto/traits#765

title: k256: remove `Scalar::conditional_add_bit`
body: The case it's actually being used for in practice is much simpler and can be easily expressed using the current functionality.

title: k256: use `U512` as the internal type for `WideScalar`
body: This is a step towards unifying the 32-bit and 64-bit implementations

title: k256: remove `pub(super)` from `WideScalar`'s `.0` field
body: This is no longer needed as the function needing access has been moved to the `WideScalar` type.

title: k256: factor `mul_shift_var(time)` into `wide` module
body:
This, combined with a small fixup to `conditional_add_bit`, ensures that all of the `Scalar`-related word size-specific gating is relegated to the `wide32.rs` vs `wide64.rs` modules.

Ideally these could be replaced with a common `U512`-based implementation which further reduces this gating, but that's left for a followup step.

title: k256+p256: use `UInt::add_mod` for scalar addition
body:
`crypto-bigint` v0.2.7 fixed a bug in `UInt::add_mod` in https://github.com/RustCrypto/utils/pull/619, and the `elliptic-curve` crate has been updated to depend on this version at a minimum.

This means we can now use it to implement scalar addition.
